headline: Hate getting robocalls? Ohio officials to crack down on scam calls and texts with new law
author: Mary Jane Sanese
sentences: Last week, Yost and 50 attorneys general urged the Federal Communications Commission to combat foreign robocalls and to make it more difficult for scammers to contact Americans by creating standardized requirements for telemarketers.

Those fees cover the attorney general's efforts to make sure they follow best practices, such as not using blocked numbers and identifying who is calling and why within the first minute of a phone call.
Civil penalties collected under the new law go into Ohio’s Telemarketing Fraud Enforcement Fund, which bankrolls investigation and litigation expenses associated with telecommunications fraud cases.
To learn more about telecommunications fraud or to file a complaint, contact the Attorney General’s office by texting “ROBO” to 888111, calling 1-800-282-0515 or visiting Ohioprotects.org.
This bill gives more power to Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost to bring cases against scammers in state court, rather than federal court, which he said will help settle cases more quickly.
The new law, sponsored by Sen. Theresa Gavarone, R-Bowling Green, criminalizes "spoofing," a favorite tactic of scammers that uses phone numbers similar to the intended target.
Keep in mind, the list only protects people from legitimate or name brand companies, which usually does not include those who use unethical practices such as spoofing.
Foreign robocall companies purchase domestic phone numbers from U.S. third party companies and use local area codes in the hopes that someone will pick up.
A new law that takes effect March 2 aims to crack down on scam calls and text messages that annoy everyone and dupe some people into losing big money.

Yost's office says Ohioans should follow some simple tips to avoid being targeted by robocallers, including:
Don't answer calls from unknown numbers.
Legitimate agencies, such as your bank or the IRS, don't call or text from unknown numbers and don't request personal info over the phone.
Senate Bill 54 also increases penalties for telecommunications fraud and criminalizes the use of internet text messages and calls.
Register your number to the FCC's National Do Not Call Registry, and file reports if you continue to receive solicitor calls.
Even if there was was no financial loss, the AG's office recommends reporting robocall or attempted scams to their office.

If an offer sounds too good to be true, it probably is, so avoid any quick decisions to give money over the phone.
"(Scammers) are finding more ways to get creative to trick people," Gavarone said in an interview.
Don't give out Social Security numbers, bank account or credit card information over the phone.
Install an application on your phone that helps block or notify you of potential scam calls.
